Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the conference "Modern Aspects of Complex Geometry," held May 14-17, 2015, on the campus of the University of Cincinnati. Conference web site: www.artsci.uc.edu/departments/math/complex_geometry_conference.html

This is a conference in the general area of geometric function theory. The event seeks to focus attention on and highlight connections between a variety of topics, including the theory of quasiconformal mappings, mappings of finite distortion, potential theory, analysis on metric spaces, and Teichmuller theory. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NFS Grant DMS-1500454 Modern Aspects of Complex Geometry

This grant was used to fund participation of 78 individuals in the conference Modern Aspects of Complex Geometry. The conference web page is located at
http://www.artsci.uc.edu/departments/math/complex_geometry_conference.html
and the schedule and abstracts of the talks presented can be found at
https://math.uc.edu/~herron/CDM-conference/MindaFest.html.

The Journal of Analysis is publishing a two-book proceedings with papers by many of the conference participants.  The first volume has been published.  The entire proceedings will constitute Volume 24 (Issue 1, June 2016 pp.1-175; Issue 2, Dec 2016, pp.177-345).

There were 78  conference participants.  Of these,

  • There were 11 women supported.
  • There were 12 underrepresented groups supported.
  • There were 10 graduate students supported.
  • There were 5 postdoctoral faculty supported.
  • There were 16 junior faculty supported.
  • There were 20 international participants.

After covering all conference expenses, the residual monies were used to fund visitors to UC, who presented talks and collaborated with UC faculty and students, and to fund conference participation of UC graduate students and faculty.  There were 13 mathematicians supported, and of these 13

  • There were 6 women supported.
  • There were 2 graduate students supported.
  • There were 3 postdoctoral faculty supported.
  • There were 2 junior faculty supported.
  • There were 3 international persons supported.
